DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang is to travel to the US next Tuesday and is expected to close the trade deal next week, while there were also comments from US Commerce Secretary Ross that they are in the end-game of trade negotiations and both sides continue to make progress on a range of issues. (Newswires)

A report suggested that US and China trade talks may have hit an impasse as this week’s negotiations had fewer details about specific discussions and results, although some analysts suggested that fewer details mean they are closer to a deal and the report also noted that both sides voiced commitment to the talks. (Global Times/PTI)

 

UK/EU

BoE voted 9-0 in favour of maintaining rates at 0.75% as expected, while it was also unanimous in maintaining the stock of UK government bond purchases at GBP 435bln and stock of corporate bonds at GBP 10bln. The MPC continued to judge that if the economy to develop broadly in line with its Inflation Report projections, it would be appropriate for ongoing tightening of monetary policy over the forecast period at a gradual pace and to a limited extent.

BoE Governor Carney said the correct path for monetary policy is dependent on how tensions between households, businesses and markets is resolved, while he also suggested that rate rises will be required following a smooth Brexit and that there are insufficient hikes in the current market curve. Furthermore, Governor Carney stated there would be some increases in rates over the next three years if economy grows as forecast and BoE Deputy Governor Broadbent stated that the downward sloping oil curve is pushing down on the bank's inflation forecasts.

Projections in the accompanying QIR were based on a path for the Bank rate that rises to around 1% by the end of the forecast horizon. (Lower than Feb assumption of 1.1%) and that MPC cited recent global developments as a factor behind this.

QIR Projections 

  • GDP Growth: 2019 Q2: 1.6% (Prev. 1.3%), 2020 Q2: 1.5% (Prev. 1.5%), 2021 Q2 2.1% (Prev. 1.8%), 2022 Q2 2.2%
  • CPI Inflation: 2019 Q2: 2.1% (Prev. 1.9%), 2020 Q2: 1.7% (Prev. 2.2%), 2021 Q2: 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%), 2022 Q2: 2.2%
  • Unemployment Rate: 2019 Q2: 3.8% (Prev. 4.0%), 2020 Q2: 3.9% (Prev. 4.1%), 2021 Q2 3.7% (Prev. 4.0%), 2022 Q2: 3.5%
  • Average Weekly Earnings: 2019: 3% (Prev. 3%), 2020: 3.5% (Prev. 3.25%), 2021: 3.75% (Prev. 3.75%)

MARKET RECAP

DowDuPont (DWDP) missed revenue expectations for Q1, CEO also announced the possible sale of six units, with a combined USD 2bln of sales. 3M (MMM) opened lower after the industrial conglomerate announced it would acquire medical device maker Acelity for USD 6.7bln. The WSJ reported that Walmart (WMT) is to trail a new store employee structure with less mid-level managers overseeing workers, the stock remained under pressure throughout the session. Tesla (TSLA) opened higher despite announcing it seeks to raise USD 2 bln via debt/equity, and also, CEO announced plan to buy 41k shares of common stock worth USD 10mln; TSLA gains were extended after a US Senator introduced the mineral security act, aimed at removing regulatory obstacles in the electric vehicle material supply chain. Qualcomm (QCOM) shares opened higher after the chipmaker beat analyst expectation on both the top and bottom lines, shrugging off a downward revision to Q3 profit guidance. Under Armour (UA, UAA) jumped higher at the open after the sportwear maker beat top and bottom-line expectations. Discovery Communications (DISCA, DISCK) shares fell despite the broadcaster authorising an additional USD 1bln in buy-backs. Apollo Global (APO) announced plans to convert from a publicly traded partnership to a corporation, effective as of Q3. Fluor (FLR) was lower after reporting a Q1 loss, missed revenue expectations by a significant amount, and the construction and engineering Co.'s CEO Seaton stepped down. Teva (TEVA) shares fell at the open, despite earnings meeting analyst expectations on the top and bottom line. AmerisourceBergen (ABC) caught a bid after the healthcare co. raised profit guidance for FY19. Energy names, including Chevron (CVX), ExxonMobil (XOM) and ConocoPhillips (COP) finished the session lower, having come under pressure from falling oil prices. The financial sector, including names such as Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and JP Morgan Chase (JPM), outperformed on the day on rising bond yields. SPX -0.2% at 2917, NDX -0.4% at 7724, DJI -0.5% at 26307.

US Treasuries once again had a slow start to the session in Asia-Pac, but as the Europeans returned from holiday, some selling was noted after poor German data. Henceforth the selling stalled after stellar US factory orders (MM 1.9% vs. prev. -0.3% & exp. 1.6%) that detracted from some weekly claims ticking up, and durable goods revisions. Thereafter, while the day’s headline grabber came from source reports suggesting an impasse on US-Sino trade-talks, little follow through was seen in USTs, which diverged on Thursday from a declining stock space. As such the block flattener noted following the US data (12k+ in TYM9 vs. 3k+ Ultra Longs) set the tone for the day with 10yr yield approaching its 50DMA towards the close, and futures settling 13 ticks lower at 123-13+. At settlement, major curve spreads were mixed, but not significantly moved. US T-note futures (M9) settled 13 ticks lower at 123-13+.

US MARKET WRAP 2 MAY 2019: BoE stands pat, markets continue to chew the fat post FOMC ahead of NFPs
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities down, dollar up, Treasuries down, crude down.

* REAR VIEW: BoE leaves rates unchanged, US Factory Orders beat, Moore withdraws nomination

* COMING UP: EZ CPI (Apr/A), CHF CPI (Apr), UK Markit serv/comp PMI (Apr), NOR unemployment (Apr), TUR CPI (Apr); US NFP (Apr), ISM Non-Mfg (Apr), Markit serv/comp PMI (Apr/F), durable goods (Mar/F), factory orders (Mar); Fed’s Clarida (v), Williams (v), Bullard (v), Daly, Kaplan, Mester.

* FRIDAYS’S EARNINGS: BRK, AMT, D

* BOE MPC REVIEW: The MPC opted to stand pat on rates at 0.75%, in a 9-0 vote, as was seen by the consensus, and dispelling outside calls for hawkish dissent in the wake of a recently published Telegraph article which floated the possibility for this meeting. Last month’s extension to the Brexit deadline continues to tie the hands of policymakers with the terms of the UK’s departure from the EU still unknown. Albeit, the MPC’s projections “continue to assume a smooth adjustment to the average range of possible outcomes for the UK’s eventual trading relationship with the EU”. Despite the ongoing limbo created by Brexit the MPC continues to judge “that, were the economy to develop broadly in line with its Inflation Report projections, an ongoing tightening of monetary policy over the forecast period, at a gradual pace and to a limited extent, would be appropriate…”. Governor Carney followed this theme up in the accompanying press conference by suggesting that if the QIR forecasts materialise, more hikes would be needed than are currently shown in the curve; Capital Economics concludes that “the key message is once again that the markets are too sanguine about the outlook for interest rates,” and it also suggests this sentiment is reflected in the accompanying inflation projections as market-pricing of one hike in the three-year horizon appears to be at odds with the MPC’s thinking that “about two 25bp hikes would be required to hit the 2% inflation target”. More specifically, on the inflation projections, policymakers assess that CPI is expected to remain fairly close to the 2% target, picking up slightly in April before easing back to just below target; 2019 Q2: 2.1% (Prev. 1.9%), 2020 Q2: 1.7% (Prev. 2.2%), 2021 Q2: 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%), 2022 Q2: 2.2%. On the growth front, as envisaged ahead of the release, the MPC revised higher their forecast for Q1 growth of 0.3% to 0.5%. However, policymakers noted that the increase is largely as a by-product of UK and EU companies stockpiling ahead of Brexit. Furthermore, this boost is expected to be temporary with Q2 growth expected to slow to 0.2%. Overall, Lloyds concludes “the Bank of England maintained its ‘wait-and-see’ approach despite the fundamentals making a stronger case for higher interest rates”, adding that “any turn in market expectations is likely to require some lifting of the ‘fog of Brexit’ and for the UK’s future relationship with the EU to become clearer”.

* NFP PREVIEW: The Street is looking for a trend-like 185k nonfarm payrolls headline, with the unemployment rate seen unchanged. Average hourly wage growth is seen ticking up, however. Payroll indicators are mixed, heading into the data, although jobless claims falling to cyclical lows in the survey week augur well; however, other gauges, like ISM’s manufacturing PMI, as well as Challenger’s assessment of the labour market call for some caution, analysts say. To download the report, please click here.

* US/CHINA TRADE: Mid-session, headlines began to circulate suggesting that US/China negotiations had hit an impasse, which was slightly at odds with earlier reports from a Chinese newspaper suggesting Chinese Foreign Minister Yi is set to travel to the US next week to close the deal, as well as source reports yesterday suggesting a deal would be closed by the end of next week. Although stocks took a turn for the worse at the time, analysts remained sceptical as to the legitimacy of the report and soon had their suspicion confirmed as the US Minister of Commerce Ross commented that talks were in the ‘end-game’ and both sides continue to make progress on a range of issues. Ross also remarked that the US is not likely to get the desired commitments from China to cut back on industrial subsidies and that expects US govt to continue to use Section 301 despite potential US/China trade deal, whilst also mentioning that business community believes getting a deal sooner is better than getting no deal in the long run.

* ECB: ECB's Weidmann said that German consumption slowdown is temporary, and an eventual pick-up is expected, adding consumption was showing initial signs of recovery. Separately, EU's Juncker said Weidmann would be a suitable candidate for the ECB President position. ECB's Rehn said the ECB shouldn't jump the gun after the first sign of stronger data. ECB's Nowotny said a medium-term perspective needs to be taken with regards to growth, and that the US and Eurozone have different measures of inflation, and it would make sense to discuss how this is measured.

* FED: Fed Board Nominee Stephen Moore withdrew his candidacy, citing unrelenting attacks on his character that had become untenable for himself and his family.

* WTI (M9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 1.79 LOWER AT 61.81/BBL; BRENT (M9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 1.43 LOWER AT 70.75/BBL. Weakness in the crude complex saw, at lows, Brent and WTI with 69- and 60- handles, respectively, on Thursday. Some suggest that it is a deepening of the technical correction in the 2019 rally. Citi suggests that the Russian crude situation may have been playing a role: "Russian crude oil production was weighing on market sentiment as output was still above the OPEC+ target, but we note the 11.23mln BPD output for April was still 70k BPD lower than in March, and the 40k BPD surplus over its 11.191mln BPD quota does not strike as particularly material, particularly after recent pipeline contamination issues and the resulting cut in Urals exports to Europe." The bank also notes that the other potential driver of the weakness is the 12.3mln BPD record weekly production estimate, as well as this week's larger-than-expected 9.9mln barrels build in crude stocks, underscoring that the WTI market is not physically tight. "In fact, total US commercial crude oil inventories of 470mln barrels for the week ended 26/April were the highest since September 2017," and "this stockpile seems to be the fundamental anchor pulling prices down at the moment."

* SPX -0.2% at 2917, NDX -0.4% at 7724, DJI -0.5% at 26307. SECTORS: Communications -0.9%, Cons Discretionary -0.0%, Cons Staples -0.1%, Energy -1.7%, Financials +0.2%, Healthcare +0.5%, Industrials -0.1%, Materials -0.6%, Tech -0.5%, Telecoms -0.5%, Utilities -0.3%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: DowDuPont (DWDP) missed revenue expectations for Q1, CEO also announced the possible sale of six units, with a combined USD 2bln of sales. 3M (MMM) opened lower after the industrial conglomerate announced it would acquire medical device maker Acelity for USD 6.7bln. The WSJ reported that Walmart (WMT) is to trail a new store employee structure with less mid-level managers overseeing workers, the stock remained under pressure throughout the session. Tesla (TSLA) opened higher despite announcing it seeks to raise USD 2 bln via debt/equity, and also, CEO announced plan to buy 41k shares of common stock worth USD 10mln; TSLA gains were extended after a US Senator introduced the mineral security act, aimed at removing regulatory obstacles in the electric vehicle material supply chain. Qualcomm (QCOM) shares opened higher after the chipmaker beat analyst expectation on both the top and bottom lines, shrugging off a downward revision to Q3 profit guidance. Under Armour (UA, UAA) jumped higher at the open after the sportwear maker beat top and bottom-line expectations. Discovery Communications (DISCA, DISCK) shares fell despite the broadcaster authorising an additional USD 1bln in buy-backs. Apollo Global (APO) announced plans to convert from a publicly traded partnership to a corporation, effective as of Q3. Fluor (FLR) was lower after reporting a Q1 loss, missed revenue expectations by a significant amount, and the construction and engineering Co.'s CEO Seaton stepped down. Teva (TEVA) shares fell at the open, despite earnings meeting analyst expectations on the top and bottom line. AmerisourceBergen (ABC) caught a bid after the healthcare co. raised profit guidance for FY19. Energy names, including Chevron (CVX), ExxonMobil (XOM) and ConocoPhillips (COP) finished the session lower, having come under pressure from falling oil prices. The financial sector, including names such as Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and JP Morgan Chase (JPM), outperformed on the day on rising bond yields.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 13 TICKS LOWER AT 123-13+. US Treasuries once again had a slow start to the session in Asia-Pac, but as the Europeans returned from holiday, some selling was noted after poor German data. Henceforth the selling stalled after stellar US factory orders (MM 1.9% vs. prev. -0.3% & exp. 1.6%) that detracted from some weekly claims ticking up, and durable goods revisions. Thereafter, while the day’s headline grabber came from source reports suggesting an impasse on US-Sino trade-talks, little follow through was seen in USTs, which diverged on Thursday from a declining stock space. As such the block flattener noted following the US data (12k+ in TYM9 vs. 3k+ Ultra Longs) set the tone for the day with 10yr yield approaching its 50DMA towards the close, and futures settling 13 ticks lower at 123-13+. At settlement, major curve spreads were mixed, but not significantly moved.

* FX WRAP: USD continued yesterday's bullish post FOMC momentum, garnering further support after higher than expected factory orders data, while participants continue to chew the fat over a more-hawkish-than-expected FOMC press conference. EUR weakened for a second day, failing to benefit from mostly positive EZ final manufacturing PMI data. GBP weakened alongside the EUR despite solid domestic manufacturing PMI data, unable to overcome FOMC dollar strength and safe haven flows into the yen. JPY strengthened amid distinct a risk-off tone that saw stocks fall to seven-day lows, with USDJPY breaking back below 111.50. Petro-currencies, including CAD, NOK and RUB, fell in unison as crude oil prices took a beating; with analysts noting this week’s large API & EIA builds and US crude production hitting fresh record highs as possible catalysts for the sell-off (as well as the mighty buck!). AUDNZD weakened further against USD, the prospect of greater monetary policy divergence continuing to weight on the Antipodeans’ relative valuations.

US, China trade talks may have hit an impasse, Chinese official media says, according to PTI
content:
• Via PTI
  • Unlike the previous negotiations, the 10th round of high-level economic and trade talks, which concluded here on Wednesday, had fewer details about specific discussions and results, state-run Global Times reported.
  • Though there remain some sticky points and tougher obstacles as they approach the end of the extensive talks, one thing remains very clear: Both sides voiced commitment to the talks, Chinese analysts said. And some even argued that fewer details mean they are closer to a deal.
  • Media reports suggest that the two sides are still discussing key issues on structural issues, such as the US accusation of unfair subsidies in China, a mechanism to verify compliance and what to do with the tariffs the two have already imposed on hundreds of billions of dollar’s worth of each other's goods.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: not so hawkish BoE follows hot on the heels of less dovish Fed
content:
USD

The Dollar has regained its post-FOMC bid and is now back to broadly firmer vs all major counterparts, with the DXY heading back up towards recent highs to retest resistance ahead of the 98.000 marker (like the 97.892 April 30 peak). To recap, the Fed shaved 5 bp off the IOER for purely technical reasons and while weaker price developments were acknowledged, Chair Powell resisted any temptation or outside influence (ie from US President Trump) to change policy guidance or raise the probability of an ease. Instead, he stressed the temporary factors depressing inflation on more than one occasion during the post-meeting press conference and Q&A and asserted equal weightings to a cut or hike, with no reason to shift from the current stance (patient pause).

NOK

The clear and marked G10 underperformer as oil prices continue to recoil and a softer Norwegian manufacturing PMI also hit the Krona more than its Sek Scandi peer that derived some support from Riksbank rhetoric downplaying sub-target Swedish inflation in wake of an even more downbeat manufacturing survey in headline terms. Indeed, Eur/Nok has extended gains beyond 9.7850 compared to Eur/Sek that remains capped around 10.7050.

GBP/CHF/CAD/JPY

All reversing earlier gains vs the Greenback, as Cable topped out again ahead of 1.3100 and gleaned little lasting support from the latest BoE super Thursday or UK construction PMI that beat consensus, but only just. In terms of the MPC, rates were held by a unanimous 9-0 vote and guidance was also maintained for gradual and limited tightening to hit the inflation goal over the forecast period. However, there was no hawkish dissent as some were contending and the QIR projections were centred on a slightly lower rate path culminating at 1% by 2021 vs 1.1% previously. Moreover, near term growth and inflation are expected to be lower than envisaged in February, with domestic demand depressed due to heightened Brexit uncertainty. Cable is now revisiting the low 1.3000 zone and retreated into 1 bn 1.3020-40 option expiry territory around the NY cut, while the Franc was undermined by a Swiss retail sales miss and sub-50 manufacturing PMI and reversed through 1.0200. The Loonie slipped through 1.3450 amidst the aforementioned steeper crude downturn and the Yen pivoted 111.50 where decent expiry interest ran off after failing to hold above the 30 DMA (111.42) as attention turns to Friday and NFP.

NZD/EUR/AUD 

Also ending Thursday’s EU session on the back foot vs the Usd as the Kiwi eyes support ahead of 0.6600 and the Aussie probes bids around 0.7000 ahead of tomorrow’s US jobs data and then RBNZ/RBA meetings next week when the prospects for reductions in both benchmark rates are relatively high – circa 50-50 and with break-evens via options suggesting higher volatility and up to 80 pip moves either way on the outcomes. Meanwhile, the single currency lost grip of the 1.1200 handle and tech supports in the form of 100 and 200 HMAs (1.1188 and 1.1194 respectively) having failed to build on gains/momentum from mostly encouraging Eurozone manufacturing PMIs with the glaring and worrying exception of Germany.

However, the 10 year UK debt future has flipped to stand relatively close to where it was before the BoE, while Bunds have now picked up the recovery baton again to forge a fresh Eurex high at 164.48 (+17 ticks vs -34 ticks at one stage) and US Treasuries just a few ticks below par aside from a flat long bond as the curve retains a flatter bias following more block trades targeting spread convergence. Next up, NY ISM and durable goods revisions.

subject: Caterpillar (CAT) affirms FY19 outlook
BoE's Governor Carney says the correct path for monetary policy is dependent on how tensions between households, businesses and markets is resolved
content:
• Current market rate curve used in forecasts is “unequal to task” of getting inflation to BoE target
  • States that rate rises will be required following a smooth Brexit; there are insufficient hikes in the current market curve
  • The yield curve may reflect risk premia on Brexit alongside global developments
  • Additional withdrawal of monetary policy stimulus is required but not at the current meeting
  • Will be short term volatility in both hard and soft UK data, though the BoE will look through this short term volatility
  • It is evident that Brexit uncertainty is raising the hurdle rate for business investment, the relative cost of investment compared with hiring has moved in favor of hiring; which will have implications for productivity
  • UK is not experiencing a debt fueled consumption boom, wage growth has picked up a little more than expected and employment is stronger
  • Businesses do not anticipate that Brexit uncertainty will be solved for some time, as such Carney says he does not believe that businesses are unreasonable in their cautiousness about investment
  • Inflation forecasts are not consistent with the BoE's inflation remit

subject: BoE May QIR Summary:
content:
Forecasts*:

GDP Growth: 2019 Q2: 1.6% (Prev. 1.3%), 2020 Q2: 1.5% (Prev. 1.5%), 2021 Q2 2.1% (Prev. 1.8%), 2022 Q2 2.2%

CPI Inflation: 2019 Q2: 2.1% (Prev. 1.9%), 2020 Q2: 1.7% (Prev. 2.2%), 2021 Q2: 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%), 2022 Q2: 2.2%

Unemployment Rate: 2019 Q2: 3.8% (Prev. 4.0%), 2020 Q2: 3.9% (Prev. 4.1%), 2021 Q2 3.7% (Prev. 4.0%), 2022 Q2: 3.5%

Average Weekly Earnings: 2019: 3% (Prev. 3%), 2020: 3.5% (Prev. 3.25%), 2021: 3.75% (Prev. 3.75%)

Key judgement 1: Global GDP growth settles at around its potential rate

Key judgement 2: UK domestic demand growth is soft in the near term, partly reflecting the impact of elevated Brexit uncertainties, before recovering

Key judgement 3: As GDP growth recovers to above the subdued rate of potential supply growth, excess demand builds

Key judgement 4: CPI inflation dips further below 2% during the first half of the forecast period , largely reflecting lower energy prices, but domestic inflationary pressures push inflation target further out
reaction_details:
• GBP/USD was drifting marginally lower heading into the decision (from 1.3057 to 1.3050). The pair knee-jerked lower at the 9-0 vote split to 1.3042 before spiking to 1.3077 as the tightening bias was maintained. Cable then dropped from the level to 1.3025 as the BoE sees no rate hike until Q4 2021
  • Meanwhile, Gilts Jun’19 futures knee jerked lowered by around 20 ticks before spiking higher and printing new session highs

subject: Zoetis Inc (ZTS) Q1 19 (USD): EPS 0.65 (exp. 0.79), Revenue 1.5bln (exp. 1.45bln).
BoE May Minutes Summary: MPC votes 9-0 in favour of maintaining rates at 0.75% - as expected
content:
Key judgements

Vote split on the base rate: MPC votes 9-0 to stand pat on rates at 0.75%

Vote split on corporate bonds: MPC votes 9-0 to maintain the stock of corporate bonds at GBP 10bln

Vote split on APF: MPC votes 9-0 to maintain the stock of UK government bond purchases at GBP 435bln

Rates: Projections in the accompanying QIR are based on a path for the Bank rate that rises to around 1% by the end of the forecast horizon. (Lower than Feb assumption of 1.1%). Note, the MPC make reference to recent global developments as a factor behind this. 

Brexit: The MPC’s projections continue to assume a smooth adjustment to the average range of possible outcomes for the UK’s eventual trading relationship with the EU. The release doesn’t provide any major update on the MPC’s view on the latest extension to the Brexit deadline.

Growth: GDP is now expected to have grown by 0.5% in Q1 2019 vs. March view of 0.3%. This increase is largely as a by-product of UK and EU companies stockpiling ahead of Brexit. This boost is expected to be temporary with Q2 growth expected to slow to 0.2%.

Inflation: Headline CPI in March of 1.9% was was inline with the Feb QIR and expectations at the Bank immediately prior to the release. Over the coming months, CPI was expected to remain fairly close to the 2% target, picking up slightly in April before easing back to just below target.

Investment: The marginally below potential growth in underlying growth is continuing to have a particularly pronounced impact on business investment. Investment is expected to pick-up at the end of the forecast period.

Labour: The labour market remains tight, with the unemployment rate expected to fall to 3.5% by the end of the forecast period.

Wages: Annual pay growth remains around 3.5% whilst unit labour costs have strengthened to rates that are above historical averages

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 2nd May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.3%] have traded indecisively this morning as the region struggles to find direction
  • In FX, the USD has lost a degree of its post-FOMC momentum, with the EUR garnering support from the EZ PMIs this morning
  • On the trade front, reports indicate that Chinese Foreign Minister Yi is to travel to the US on Tuesday
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US Initial Jobless Claims and Labour Costs, US Factory Orders, BoE Rate Decision, QIR and Press Conference, ECB's Praet,
  • Earnings: Activision Blizzard, Exelon

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed as the region partially shrugged off the negative lead from US where all major indices were pressured, and the S&P 500 snapped a 3-day streak of record closes after Fed Chair Powell downplayed prospects for looser policy at the post-FOMC presser. ASX 200 (-0.6%) traded negative with the index led lower by financials after AMP Capital reported net cash outflows widened in Q1 and with ‘Big 4’ bank NAB also weighed after it lowered its interim dividend by 16%. Elsewhere, both KOSPI (+0.4%) and Hang Seng (+0.8%) recovered from early losses on return from Labour Day holidays amid US-China trade optimism as reports suggested a trade deal could be possible by the end of next week, while China also recently announced several measures to open up its financial sector to foreign companies in a concession to the US. As a reminder, Japan and mainland China remained closed for holidays.

Chinese Foreign Minister Yi is to travel to the US next Tuesday, expected to close the trade deal next week., according to a Chinese newspaper. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May is reportedly preparing to accept that customs rules with the EU will be maintained for years post-Brexit in a deal with opposition Labour party. (The Times) However, separate reports state that a senior cabinet minister suggested a deal involving a customs union could be backed by as few as 90 Tory MPs and would mean a slew of resignations the government. (Guardian)

UK government may drop plans to conduct a 3-year spending review and instead opt for a 1-year programme amid Brexit fallout and uncertainty on PM May's future. (Guardian)

ECB's Nowotny says that regarding growth a medium-term perspective needs to be taken and that the US and Euro Zone have different measures of inflation, it would make sense to discuss how this is measured. (Newswires)

 

UK Markit/CIPS Cons PMI (Apr) 50.5 vs. Exp. 50.3 (Prev. 49.7)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Apr) 47.9 vs. Exp. 47.8 (Prev. 47.8)

- German Markit/BME Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 44.4 vs. Exp. 44.5 (Prev. 44.5)

- French Markit Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 50.0 vs. Exp. 49.6 (Prev. 49.6)

- Italian Markit/IHS Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 49.1 vs. Exp. 47.8 (Prev. 47.4)

- Swedish PMI Manufacturing Sector (Apr) 50.9 (Prev. 52.8, Rev. 52.5)

- Spanish Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.2 (Prev. 50.9)

- Swiss Manufacturing PMI (Apr) 48.5 vs. Exp. 50.5 (Prev. 50.3)

 

EQUITIES

Major European indices have traded indecisively this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.3%], as the region struggles to find direction post-FOMC where US indices were subdued but Asia did manage to somewhat shrug off the negativity. It is also worth bearing in mind that markets are playing catchup due to yesterday Labour Day holiday for much of Europe which may account for some of the volatility. Sectors are subdued this morning, although there was some mild outperformance in Healthcare and utility names at the open. This morning’s notable earnings release came from Shell (+2.3%) who beat on their Q1 adj. profit and have begun the next tranche of their share buyback programme, with the heavyweight lifting energy names higher in-spite of lower oil prices. Separately, Volkswagen (+4.5%) are towards the top of the Stoxx 600 after beating on Q1 revenue and confirming their FY outlook for car sales. Also of note are Bayer (+3.3%) whose share prices are supported this morning by the US Environmental Protections agency stating that glyphosate is not a carcinogen. Elsewhere Lloyds (-1.0%) are in the red post-earnings as the Co’s Q1 statutory pre-tax profit missed on Co. complied estimates, Lloyds have also made an additional PPI provision of GBP 100mln.

 

FX

DXY - Although the Greenback has a lost a degree of its post-Powell recovery momentum, the index remains above 97.500 and on a more stable footing as the Fed chair refrained from flagging any shift towards a rate cut or even a hint that soft inflation could tip the policy balance from neutral to dovish. In fact, after the 5 bp IOER reduction he stressed that the move was technical rather than fundamental and repeatedly downplayed slowing price developments as transitory. Hence, the DXY has rebounded from sub-97.200 lows and just above a Fib support level (97.121), albeit with the Buck now mixed vs G10 peers.

EUR - The single currency has drawn a bit more encouragement from the run of Eurozone manufacturing PMIs, as all bar Germany posted better than expected headlines, including Italy that rebounded relatively firmly following a return to GDP growth in Q1. Eur/Usd is back above 1.1200 as a result having probed a few pips below the 200 HMA at 1.1194, but the headline pair may be hampered by heavy option expiry interest stretching from 1.1200-10 through 1.1225-40 and up to 1.1250 (1.5 bn, 2 bn and 1.1 bn respectively). Moreover, chart resistance could cap the upside given the 30 DMA at 1.1236 and a Fib at 1.1242.

NZD/AUD - The Kiwi and Aussie are marginally outperforming vs major counterparts amidst reports that a US-China trade accord may be in the offing as soon as next week and at the end of the next talks to take place in Washington, with Beijing said to be offering concessions in return for a recent olive branch from the US. Nzd/Usd is hovering between 0.6620-39 and Aud/Usd within a 0.7012-29 range as the Aud/Nzd cross sits just under 1.0600 and attention down under turns towards next week’s RBNZ and RBA policy meetings (notwithstanding NFP tomorrow of course). Both rate calls are seen tight with swap pricing not far from evens for easing, but as NAB contends that it may be to early for the RBA options are indicating higher break-evens as a result (circa 80 pips).

GBP/CAD/CHF/JPY - All on a more even keel vs the Greenback, with Cable straddling 1.3050 and braced for BoE super Thursday after only deriving modest support from a return to growth in the UK construction sector. However, the Pound is consolidating gains relative to the Euro over 0.8600 amidst some talk that 1 MPC voter could break ranks and switch into hike mode – full preview on the headline feed and via the Research Suite. Conversely, the Loonie is struggling to hold above 1.3450 against the backdrop of ongoing weakness in oil prices, while the Franc is back down near 1.0200 and sub-1.1400 against the Euro in wake of weak Swiss retail sales and a contractionary manufacturing PMI. The Yen has also retreated from Wednesday’s pre-FOMC peaks through 111.50 and the 30 DMA (111.42) into decent option expiries (1.2 bn between 111.50-55).

NOK/SEK - Disappointing Scandi manufacturing PMIs vs consensus and previous readings have soured sentiment to a degree, but Eur/Nok has also been driven higher by the aforementioned crude retracement, to 9.7400+ at one stage vs Eur/Sek topping out just shy of 10.7050.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and Gilts have both rebounded further from worst levels, with the former erasing all and a bit more of its losses at 165.34 vs 164.97 and Tuesday’s 165.31 pre-Labour Day break Eurex close. Another poor German manufacturing survey is the obvious suspect behind the recovery, while chart impulses may also be contributing again as trend support held at 164.95. In contrast, the 10 year UK benchmark only reached 127.48 (still -13 ticks, albeit 28 ticks off the Liffe trough) following a modest construction PMI beat and now awaiting the BoE from noon, while US Treasuries are softer and the curve more mixed after the Fed reverberations as the focus shifts to weekly claims in the run up to Friday’s BLS release.

COMMODITIES

Brent (-1.0%) and WTI (-0.9%) prices are lower, with oil prices subdued as this week's large crude stockpile builds overshadows Iranian waiver woes and Venezuela concerns, although some of downside in the complex could be attributed to a firmer post-FOMC Dollar.  In terms of recent newsflow Russia’s April oil production stood at 11.23mln BPD vs. 11.3mln in March, with these levels being relatively in-fitting with recent IFX reports. Additionally, the Russian Energy Ministry have stated that they are to keep May's production in-line with the prior agreements; which was agreed at a reduction of 228k BPD (from the October baselines of 11.4mln BPD) in the OPEC pact.

Gold (-0.5%) was also afflicted by the surge in the Dollar, with the yellow metal unable to recover from this downside, in spite of the Buck easing off highs, and is currently trading firmly at the bottom of its USD 7/oz range. While copper prices are still around 2-month lows as the red metal is missing the support of its largest buyer China which is on Labour Day holiday for the remainder of the week.

World Gold Council said Q1 global gold demand rose 7% Y/Y to around 1.05K tons and noted continued growth in central bank purchases. (Newswires)

Russian April oil production stood at 11.23mln BPD vs. 11.3mln BPD in March, according to the Energy Ministry. (Newswires)

- Russian Energy Ministry states that Russia will keep May's oil production in-line with the prior agreements

EU commission state the EU are to seek to increase LNG Gas imports from the US to 8bln cubic meters per year by 2023, which is over double the level in 2018. (Newswires)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo states that it is impossible to eliminate Iranian oil from the market., according to Shana. (Newswires)

Poland's Energy Ministry state that they released 500k T of strategic oil reserves on April 26th and 300k T on April 30th, due to the suspension of polluted oil supplies from Russia. (Newswires)

subject: Chinese Foreign Minister Yi is to travel to the US next Tuesday, expected to close the trade deal next week., according to a Chinese newspaper
analysis_details: • This confirms source reports which stated a trade deal between US and China is said to be possible by the end of next week. . Reports noted US and China are said to have neared a deal to roll-back some tariffs which could be announced by the end of next week, while both sides have reached an understanding on how to enforce the agreement although the sources cautioned that details still need to be worked out when a Chinese delegation arrives in Washington on 8 May. Furthermore, there was said to be a general agreement on a plan for the US to immediately remove a 10% tariff on a portion of the USD 200bln worth of Chinese imports but the USD 50bln tranche of 25% tariffs may remain potentially to after 2020.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures track post-FOMC downturn pre-UK construction PMI and BoE
content: UK debt and STIR contracts are already conceding ground on BoE super Thursday and the 2nd early month PMI as the Fed confounded dovish market expectations and ‘prompting’ from US President Trump by maintaining a neutral policy bias via no inclination to cut or hike rates, with Chair Powell pretty adamant that slowing inflation will prove to be a temporary phenomenon. The 10 year bond gapped down 38 ticks initially and dipped a bit further to an early 127.20 Liffe low vs Wednesday’s 127.61 settlement before paring some lost ground to a recovery high at 127.34, while the 3 month strip is nestling just off worst levels of -0.5 to -3.5 ticks awaiting the construction survey, MPC policy verdict, minutes, QIR and Governor Carney news conference.

Bunds: bearish return from Labour Day and into Eurozone manufacturing PMIs
content: The 10 year German benchmark was marked down 15 ticks from the off in catch-up or corrective trade after missing the first session of the month due to the May 1 holiday, and subsequently extended losses to 29 ticks from Monday’s 165.31 close on follow-through selling in wake of the FOMC after an early Eurex recovery stalled at 165.26. However, Bunds have regained some composure more recently amidst underlying bids ahead of 165.00 and the EU cash bourse opens as attention switches to the run of delayed manufacturing PMIs so see if there is any improvement in line with recent more encouraging hard data, like preliminary CPI and GDP. Also on Thursday’s agenda, several ECB speakers and hefty French supply.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

2nd May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mixed as the region partially shrugged off the negative lead from US where all major indices were pressured, and the S&P 500 snapped a 3-day streak of record closes after Fed Chair Powell downplayed prospects for looser policy at the post-FOMC presser. ASX 200 (-0.7%) traded negative with the index led lower by financials after AMP Capital reported net cash outflows widened in Q1 and with ‘Big 4’ bank NAB also weighed after it lowered its interim dividend by 16%. Elsewhere, both KOSPI (+0.5%) and Hang Seng (+0.6%) recovered from early losses on return from Labour Day holidays amid US-China trade optimism as reports suggested a trade deal could be possible by the end of next week, while China also recently announced several measures to open up its financial sector to foreign companies in a concession to the US. As a reminder, Japan and mainland China remained closed for holidays.

FTSE

RBS (RBS LN) – Co. are launching NatWest Tyl, a new merchant acquiring for small and medium sized businesses; as the Co. are returning to payment business after the Co. were forced to sell their payment business (Worldpay) during the financial crisis. (FT)

GVC Holdings (GVC LN) – Co. is at risk of further shareholder revolt after the CEO and Chairman received around GBP 28mln in pay following large share awards. (Times

Ocado (OCDO LN) – Co. state that 24.2% of votes at the AGM were against the director’s remuneration policy, and 25.4% opposed their pay report. All resolutions proposed at the AGM were passed by shareholders (Times/Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – NICE has published a recommendation on durvalumab, as a treatment for NSCLC in adults. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – Q1 underlying profit before tax GBP 6.9mln vs. Prev. GBP 10mln. Y/Y loan growth GBP 4.2bln vs. Prev. GBP 5.5bln. Co. says Q1 has been challenging. Since January, a small number of large commercial and partnership customers made withdrawals. Separately, following an accounting error by the Co. where they mischaracterised the risk of some loans in January, depositors removed over GBP 500mln from the Co. Co. state that ‘adverse sentiment’ led to a small number of business customers going elsewhere; resulted in a 4% QQ deposit reduction. (Newswires/FT/Times)

Restaurant Group (RTN LN) – Co. have appointed Andy Hornby as their CEO. (Telegraph)

BROKER MOVES

BUNZL (BNZL LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

SAINSBURYS (SBRY LN) REITERATED UNDERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

METRO BANK (MTRO LN) REITERATED UNDERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

Co. set aside EUR 1bln for legal issues. Co. confirms FY 18 outlook for car sales, revenue and adj. operating profit. Co. sees rising global economic risks. April vehicles sales 31.3k, +8.7%. (Fox) For reference, the Co. holds 63.04% of T-Mobile shares.

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

PAN EUROPE

ING Groep (ING NA) – Q1 Adj. net EUR 1.12bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.19bln. Adj. PBT EUR 1.58bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.60bln. Total underlying income EUR 4.58bln vs. Prev. EUR 4.46bln. Co. declines to comment on a possible tie-up with Commerzbank (CBK GY). (Newswires)

Red Electrica (REE SM) – Q1 EBITDA EUR 405.9mln vs. Exp. EUR 405mln, revenue EUR 499.7mln vs. Prev. EUR 497mln and net EUR 191mln vs. Prev. EUR 189.1mln. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 2nd May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • FOMC left rates unchanged as expected and announced a ‘technical’ cut in the IOER; Chair Powell stated that he does not see the case for moving policy in either direction
  • Asian indices were mixed, as most of the region returned from market holidays, somewhat diverging from the negative Wall St lead
  • Sources state that a US-China trade deal may be possible by next week, with reports indicating that there has been significant progress; however, the details still need to be worked out
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Retail Sales, EZ Manufacturing PMIs, UK Construction PMI, US Initial Jobless Claims and Labour Costs, US Factory Orders, BoE Rate Decision, Inflation Report and Press Conference, ECB's Praet, supply from France
  • Earnings: Activision Blizzard, DowDuPont, Exelon, BNP Paribas, Volkswagen, Shell

 

FOMC

- FOMC left the Fed Funds Rate rates unchanged at between 2.25%-2.50% as expected with the decision unanimous, while it cut interest on excess reserves (IOER) by 5bps to 2.35% to keep fed funds rate well within target range

- Fed stated that overall and core inflation have declined on a 12-month basis but added that data received since March indicates economic activity has risen at a solid pace and it removed its reference to low inflation being due to energy prices. FOMC added job gains have been solid although growth of household spending as well as business and fixed investment have slowed.

- Fed reiterated patience as it determines what future adjustments to rate might be appropriate and are to roll over principal payments from its holding of treasury securities that exceed USD 15bln as previously announced.

- Fed Chair Powell commented during the press conference that the change in IOER was technical and not a shift in Fed policy, while he added that a small deviation outside of Fed funds target range would not be important and suggested they could look at the idea of a Repo facility at an upcoming meeting. Furthermore, Powell commented that the inflation drop in early 2019 was unexpected and there might be transitory factors at work, while he does not see case for moving policy in either direction and that the data is not pushing Fed in either direction.

The press conference was viewed as less dovish than some had hoped for as Powell attempted to navigate a neutral line and suggested the IOER was a technical adjustment that does not represent any shift in the Fed's policy stance, while markets also focused on the view that the unexpected decline in core inflation is likely to be transitory. In addition, Powell was pressed on conditions that the Fed would need to see before considering cutting rates but seemed to be reticent to be drawn into the question and instead reiterated the Fed's policy targets. 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed as the region partially shrugged off the negative lead from US where all major indices were pressured, and the S&P 500 snapped a 3-day streak of record closes after Fed Chair Powell downplayed prospects for looser policy at the post-FOMC presser. ASX 200 (-0.7%) traded negative with the index led lower by financials after AMP Capital reported net cash outflows widened in Q1 and with ‘Big 4’ bank NAB also weighed after it lowered its interim dividend by 16%. Elsewhere, both KOSPI (+0.5%) and Hang Seng (+0.6%) recovered from early losses on return from Labour Day holidays amid US-China trade optimism as reports suggested a trade deal could be possible by the end of next week, while China also recently announced several measures to open up its financial sector to foreign companies in a concession to the US. As a reminder, Japan and mainland China remained closed for holidays.

 

A trade deal between US and China is said to be possible by the end of next week, according to sources. Reports noted US and China are said to have neared a deal to roll-back some tariffs which could be announced by the end of next week, while both sides have reached an understanding on how to enforce the agreement although the sources cautioned that details still need to be worked out when a Chinese delegation arrives in Washington on 8 May. Furthermore, there was said to be a general agreement on a plan for the US to immediately remove a 10% tariff on a portion of the USD 200bln worth of Chinese imports but the USD 50bln tranche of 25% tariffs may remain potentially to after 2020. (Newswires/WSJ/Politico) 

UK/EU

UK PM May is reportedly preparing to accept that customs rules with the EU will be maintained for years post-Brexit in a deal with opposition Labour party. (The Times) However, separate reports state that a senior cabinet minister suggested a deal involving a customs union could be backed by as few as 90 Tory MPs and would mean a slew of resignations the government. (Guardian)

 

UK government may drop plans to conduct a 3-year spending review and instead opt for a 1-year programme amid Brexit fallout and uncertainty on PM May's future. (Guardian) 

FX

 

USD firmed following the post-FOMC press conference which was less dovish than some had hoped. This weakened EUR/USD briefly below 1.1200 although it has since recovered as a large option expiry of EUR 1.2bln at the aforementioned level attracts price action, while GBP/USD retreated from near 1.3100 before finding support around its 100DMA of 1.3044. Elsewhere, antipodeans also weakened in the aftermath of the FOMC but have nursed some losses in Asia trade with AUD/USD recovering from near the 0.7000 level, while there were also comments from NAB’s CEO who dismissed calls for an RBA rate cut next week as he views it as unnecessary and suggested it would do little to stimulate the economy.

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were subdued overnight with price action dampened amid the mixed risk tone and after the FOMC. As such, WTI crude futures were kept rangebound which was in contrast to the prior day’s swings as bearish inventory data initially weighed on prices which gradually recovered amid supply concerns associated with Iran and Venezuela. Elsewhere, gold prices were heavily pressured as the greenback surged post-FOMC and copper languished following its recent slip to 2½-month lows not helped by the absence of its largest buyer China.

 

World Gold Council said Q1 global gold demand rose 7% Y/Y to around 1.05K tons and noted continued growth in central bank purchases. (Newswires)

 

Oman Oil Minister said the June OPEC meeting will be to extend OPEC cuts and that the oil market will remain balanced even post end of Iranian crude import waivers, while he added USD 70/bbl is an appropriate price for producers and consumers. (Newswires)

US

USTs floundered at the start of the day on thin volumes ahead of the Fed, with modest starting gains surrendered following a better than expected ADP report, with some traders noting a large block flattener of over 13k FVM9s vs over 2K ultra longs. Thereafter, however, ISM manufacturing missed at 52.8 vs. exp. 55 which added upside to the complex, with a large block buyer of 8k USM9 calls noted. The meat of the day, however, was then the Fed’s decision, which saw the curve steepening and treasuries pushing higher, with increased volumes on the front end post the unchanged rate and IOER 5bps cut to 2.35%.  Yields broke the 10th April 2.461% low, but the move was faded after Powell stated the “surprising” inflation prints could be transitory, and the IOER cut was purely “technical”. Thereafter the curve flattened and treasuries slipped to session lows heading into the close. US T-note futures (M9) settled 3 ticks lower at 123-18+.
